sub_topic: Finding the Ramsey number of a graph.
message_1:
What is the Ramsey number of R(3,3)?
(Note: R(a,b) represents the smallest number of vertices in a graph such that either a vertices induce a subgraph with no edges, or b vertices induce a subgraph with all possible edges.)
message_2: The Ramsey number R(3,3) is 6. This means that in any graph with 6 vertices, there will always be either a set of 3 vertices that form a triangle (a complete subgraph with all possible edges) or a set of 3 vertices that form an independent set (a subgraph with no edges).
